text:
If you know very well about what are you writting, you can write up to 1000 words in 30-60 min. But if you have to do research, you will need like 3-4 hours.
In my case, travel blog, I need 2 hours for a simple post (1 hour write, 1 hour photo processing), and 4 hours for long posts (1 hour write, 2 hours research, 1 hour photo processing)

elements.text:

text:
7 in 7 days would kill me, honestly, even if they were easy (that assumes you work 7 days a week, which may not be the case!).

I aim for a max of 3 a week if they're shorter (under 750 words). For mental health reasons, I have a minimum 7-day turnaround for all assignments and it goes up from there.

As for how long it takes...that really depends. My easiest have probably been around an hour (including research), while my more in-depth ones probably 3-4hrs for something around 1,000 words. But again, it really depends on the industry, client, and requirements.

As for how long it takes...that really depends. My easiest have probably been around an hour (including research), while my more in-depth ones probably 3-4hrs for something around 1,000 words. But again, it really depends on the industry, client, and requirements.

and

text:
Cool spread of answers here!

If I am writing a journal entry and going pure stream of consciousness I can clock in at like, 2500 words per hour.

So if the blog topic is something with which I'm intimately familiar/confident with, a big piece + research + editing can take as little as a few hours. It just feels like I'm slightly reordering and polishing those stream-of-consciousness thoughts.

The further I get from familiarity, the more time gets shunted over to research. A 750 word piece could take days as I hum and haw over a reference here or a phrasing there.

And like <@U024Z91H0KC>, I always build in a minimum SLA buffer for client work. Even if it's technically possible to crank out a first draft in a few hours I do not want that to become "the norm" for anyone.

text:
:woman-raising-hand::skin-tone-4: Basic, content-marketing-101 question — or is it? I haven’t found basic, straightforward answers (maybe they just don’t exist) and have been thinking about this often. Not only because of content marketing, but due to my commitment to DEI:

> What does “relevant alt text” mean to *you*? What’s your approach to alt text? Do you purely think of accessibility — and if so, with long, detailed descriptions? Purely SEO? A mix of both?
Would love to hear your thoughts and experiences. Thank you! :facepunch::skin-tone-4:

elements.text: Basic, content-marketing-101 question — or is it? I haven’t found basic, straightforward answers (maybe they just don’t exist) and have been thinking about this often. Not only because of content marketing, but due to my commitment to DEI:
What does “relevant alt text” mean to
you
? What’s your approach to alt text? Do you purely think of accessibility — and if so, with long, detailed descriptions? Purely SEO? A mix of both?
Would love to hear your thoughts and experiences. Thank you!

text: I had some great leadership a few jobs ago from our accessibility lead. They said it means say what the image is. But it also then means only choose images that add to the content (not just some rando thing from unsplash). :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I had some great leadership a few jobs ago from our accessibility lead. They said it means say what the image is. But it also then means only choose images that add to the content (not just some rando thing from unsplash).

text: So great that you had the opportunity to work with an accessibility lead, Brendan. Thanks for sharing!

elements.text: So great that you had the opportunity to work with an accessibility lead, Brendan. Thanks for sharing!

text: <@UUXMCJQ15> I like that approach. I just realised the challenge there in terms of visual branding too. In my former company, we often had images like <https://blog.unmind.com/redefining-resilience-why-we-need-to-take-a-whole-person-approach|this highly stylised image> — I’m definitely not convinced I could write a good alt text for this one :sweat_smile:

text:
100% agreement with Brenden: describe the image. Relevant alt text is 95% an accessibility move (and 5% an SEO move)

> . In my former company, we often had images like <https://blog.unmind.com/redefining-resilience-why-we-need-to-take-a-whole-person-approach|this highly stylised image> — I’m definitely not convinced I could write a good alt text for this one :sweat_smile:
Here’s my shot:

“A stack of four blocks illustrating the concept of whole-person, whole-organization resilience, featuring these objects next to and on the stack: a heart with an EKG graph, a crescent moon, an apple, and a plug and cable linking two blocks together”

text: I have a client that's running into issues getting  client's logos (or at least the clients they want) approved to use on their website. Has your team had to offer a free month of access to your app or anything to incentivize them greenlighting something like this?

text: Gimme a bit more context? Are these app users? Service clients? Something else?

elements.text: Gimme a bit more context? Are these app users? Service clients? Something else?

text:
Sometimes it helps if you already have a couple of big names on board and can pitch a brand having its logo alongside those: "We're planning to feature Amazon, Nike, American Express, and you. Does that work?"

(At the very least, it may ease their anxiety that they'd be the only Big Fancy brand or that your product is shady/unworthy of their brand name.)

elements.text:

text: Thanks <@UJDPMTREY> good point. None of these are the Nikes of the world though. :sweat_smile:

good point. None of these are the Nikes of the world though.

text: I’m not a fan of negotiating like that after the fact. My company typically tries to get the approvals up front on renewals, which can potentially be used as leverage on price.

elements.text: I’m not a fan of negotiating like that after the fact. My company typically tries to get the approvals up front on renewals, which can potentially be used as leverage on price.

text:
It’s a lot easier to produce at a high-volume when you have pieces in lots of different stages … so if you get stuck for whatever reason, whether it’s writer’s block, a huge hole in the research, or the article just isn’t working for whatever reason, you have somethjng else to move forward on. Try to get assignments (or assign yourself) as far in advance as you can. You might have actually started one of your 7 deliveries per week 2 or 3 weeks prior, but no one else needs to know that ;)

Once writing gets into factory mode, you lose that spark of creativity that makes it unique and interesting to read.

Once writing gets into factory mode, you lose that spark of creativity that makes it unique and interesting to read.
